item.itunes:summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued a consumer warning advising against eating tomalley in American Lobster (Maine Lobster), regardless of where the lobster was harvested, because of potential contamination with dangerous levels of the toxins that cause paralytic shellfish poisoning (PSP).

item.title: Deep Brain Stimulation for Depression
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Deep brain stimulation, an experimental and invasive treatment that involves stimulating the brain with electrical signals, may help treat otherwise difficult to cure depression, a new study reports.

item.title: Enzymes for Muscle Mass
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have discovered that adding an enzyme supplement may help individuals who are trying to increase muscle mass.

item.title: Maternal Zinc for Baby Health
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the month of August has the highest number of births making a recent study all the more relevant. Researchers from George Washington University's School of Public Health and Health Services in Washington, D.C., found that zinc supplementation in pregnant women may contribute to the health of their children.

item.title: Meditation for Delayed HIV Progression
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Practicing mindfulness meditation may help delay the disease progression in HIV patients, a new study reports.

item.title: Yerba Mate
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Yerba mate, also known as erva-mate in Portuguese, originates from South America and is extracted from the dried leaves of Ilex paraguariensis. Two new studies examined its protective effects.

item.title: TGFBR1 gene Increases Risk of Colon Cancer
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Genomics & Proteomics, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have identified a genetic abnormality that makes a person about nine times more likely to develop colorectal cancer.

item.title: FDA Allows Irradiation of Leafy Greens
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) will allow food producers to zap raw iceberg lettuce and spinach with enough radiation to kill dangerous germs like salmonella and E. coli. The greens will most likely go under the beam after they are bagged – preventing the risk of recontamination.

item.title: Treadmill Exercise may Retrain Body and Brain after Stroke
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have found that regularly exercising on a treadmill may help stroke patients learn to walk correctly again by rewiring parts of the brain – even if the stroke happened years ago. Using a treadmill may also improve walking and overall fitness better than stretching, the standard exercise prescribed after a stroke.

item.title: Harmful Metals Found in Some Ayurvedic Medicines
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: A new study found that Ayurvedic medicines made in the United States and India and sold on the Internet may contain unacceptable levels of harmful metals, including lead, mercury and arsenic.

item.title: Long-Term Incense Use Linked to Cancer
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness
item.itunes:summary: Regularly inhaling the smoke from incense may increase the risk of most respiratory tract cancers, a new study suggests. The increased risk was observed in both smokers and non-smokers.

item.title: Marinade Does More than Enhance Taste
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: Marinating meat before tossing it on the grill may do more than just add flavor. Researchers have discovered that marinades rich in spices may help reduce cancer-causing compounds found in steak.

item.title: Protein that Produces "Good" Fat Identified
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Genomics & Proteomics
item.itunes:summary: A pair of studies has made discoveries about the way mammals make and use different types of fat that may one day lead to new treatments for obesity.

item.title: Reconsidering the Diverticulosis Diet
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: People with the digestive disorder diverticulosis may no longer have to worry about eating hard-to-digest foods like popcorn, corn and nuts. For many years, it was suspected that these foods increase the risk of complications, such as infection, but a new study found that they may actually have protective effects.

item.title: Antioxidants may Prevent "Chemo-Brain"
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new animal study shows that antioxidant therapy may protect against memory and attention problems commonly seen in cancer patients who are undergoing chemotherapy.

item.title: Do Energy Drinks Need Warning Labels?
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: According to researchers from Johns Hopkins University, energy drinks should bear labels stating their caffeine content and warning of their potential health problems. Although some drinks, like Red Bull®, contain moderate amounts of caffeine, others were shown to be equivalent to more than 14 cans of Coca Cola®.

item.title: Can Fish Help Prevent Childhood Eczema?
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: According to a recent study, infants who are fed fish may have a lower risk of developing eczema, an allergic skin disease, in early childhood.

item.title: FDA Proposes Guidelines For Genetically Engineered Animals
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Genomics & Proteomics, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) released proposed guidelines for how it would regulate genetically engineered (GE) animals to ensure that they are safe for humans and the environment.

item.title: Safety of Tanning Beds Questioned
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Although tanning beds have been marketed as a possible safe alternative to outdoor sun, evidence shows that ultraviolet (UV) rays are harmful, regardless of where they come from.

item.title: Sweet Smells May Promote Sweet Dreams
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: The scent of flowers may lead to pleasant dreams, a new study reports.

item.title: Learned Safety and Antidepressants
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new animal study, published in Neuron, may provide a good model system for testing cellular and molecular interactions between antidepressants and behavioral treatments for depression.

item.title: Obesity Linked to Less Satisfaction while Eating
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Genomics & Proteomics, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study found that some people may be predisposed to obesity because the rewards centers in their brains do not respond as well as the average person. In order to boost their satisfaction from eating, they may overindulge or choose high-calorie foods, causing them to gain more weight.

item.title: Many Doctors Prescribe Placebos
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new survey found that about half of internists and rheumatologists offer fake prescriptions, or placebos, to help their patients feel better. A placebo is any substance that is believed to have no pharmacological effect on the condition being treated.

item.title: Milk Immunotherapy: A Possible Treatment for Milk Allergies?
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: In a recent study published in the Journal of Allergy & Clinical Immunology, children with milk allergies who received low doses of milk that were gradually increase over time, experienced decreased symptoms.

item.title: Heavy Metals Found in International Wines
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Product Advisories |
item.itunes:summary: According to scientists, red and white wines from various countries contain potentially harmful amounts of at least seven heavy metals, including vanadium, chromium, manganese, nickel, copper, zinc and lead. The authors suggest that these metals may pose health risks in people who consume wine frequently over an extended period of time.

item.title: High-Fat Diet Linked to Alzheimer's
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A high-fat diet may play a role in the development of Alzheimer's disease, a new animal study suggests. A diet rich in animal fat and low in omega-3 fatty acids reportedly increased brain markers linked to Alzheimer's disease.

item.title: Hydrogen Sulfide may Regulate Blood Pressure
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have discovered that hydrogen sulfide, a common gas that smells like rotten eggs, may help regulate blood pressure.

item.title: Purple Tomatoes Increased Lifespan of Cancer-Prone Mice
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Genomics & Proteomics, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that tomatoes genetically altered to be rich in antioxidants may increase the life span in mice that are predisposed to cancer.

item.title: Selenium, Vitamin E Ineffective for Prostate Cancer Prevention
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: The government halted a major study that was testing whether vitamin E and selenium, either taken alone or together, may help prevent prostate cancer. An early review of the data showed that the supplements were ineffective and may possibly lead to health risks.

item.title: Study: Placebo Acupuncture Associated with Higher Pregnancy Rate
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Acupuncture is often used during in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatments, despite the limited evidence of effectiveness. In a recent study, however, placebo acupuncture was unexpectedly linked to a higher rate of pregnancy than real acupuncture.

item.title: Water Aerobics may Decrease Pain of Childbirth
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Pregnant women who perform water aerobics may experience less pain during delivery, a new study suggests.

item.title: Caregiving Linked to Improved Longevity
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that caregivers may derive health benefits from their altruistic efforts. In a recent study, older people who spent at least 14 hours a week taking care of their disabled spouses lived longer than those who did not.

item.title: Eggs may Play a Role in Type 2 Diabetes
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Eating more than one egg a week may be linked to an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, according to a new study.

item.title: Hairspray may be Linked to Common Birth Defect
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Environmental Resources, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Genomics & Proteomics, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New research suggests that pregnant mothers who are exposed to hairspray at work may be more likely to have boys with a common genital defect called hypospadias. This condition occurs when the opening of the urethra is on the underside of the urethra instead of at the tip.

item.title: Vitamins C and E Fall Short in Recent Studies
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Vitamins are widely used to treat and prevent various illnesses, including cancer and heart disease. Although evidence is still inconclusive in these areas, recent research has not demonstrated significant benefits.

item.title: Sedentary Lifestyle may be Linked to Headaches
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New research suggests that a sedentary lifestyle may increase the risk of having frequent headaches.

item.title: Anticancer Compounds Identified in Olive Oil
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have identified anti-cancer compounds in extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) that may lead to a reduced risk of certain breast cancers.

item.title: Antioxidants may Improve Pain in Patients with Chronic Pancreatitis
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: In a recent study, antioxidant supplementation improved pain and reduced levels of oxidative stress in patients with chronic pancreatitis, an inflammatory disease of the pancreas. The main symptom of chronic-pancreatitis is abdominal pain, which can last anywhere from hours to days. However, effective pain-relieving medication for this condition is currently lacking.

item.title: HRT may be Linked to Decreased Risk of Colorectal Cancer
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) may reduce the risk of colorectal cancer in women, especially after therapy is completed, a new study suggests.

item.title: Mind-Body Therapy May Improve Pelvic Pain
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that a mind-body therapy called Mensendieck somatocognitive therapy may reduce long-term (chronic) pelvic pain in women. The effects lasted several months after the treatment ended.

item.title: Phosphates Possibly Linked to Lung Cancer Risk
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A diet rich in phosphate accelerated the growth of lung cancers in mice and may increase the risk of tumors in those predisposed to the disease, a preliminary study reports.

item.title: Stevia Sweetener Approved
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, New Products
item.itunes:summary: Stevia The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently approved the use of Truvia™ and PureVia™, zero-calorie sweeteners made from the stevia plant, for use in foods and beverages. These newly approved sweeteners are purified forms of stevia called rebaudioside A.

item.title: Vitamin C May Affect Blood Pressure
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have found a possible link between high levels of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and lower blood pressure in women.

item.title: Fitness may Help Prevent Mental Decline in Older Adults
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have discovered that older adults who are in good physical shape may have a reduced risk of mental decline, likely due to healthy blood flow to the brain.

item.title: Bisphenol Controversy Continues
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Environmental Resources, Evidence-Based Research
item.itunes:summary: A preliminary study calls into question what is known about bisphenol A (BPA) exposure and how it is removed from the body. BPA is a chemical commonly used in hardened plastics and is often found in baby bottles, water bottles and eyeglass lenses.

item.title: AHA: Omega-6 Beneficial for Heart Health
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: The American Heart Association (AHA) released a new science advisory recommending that at least 5-10 percent of daily calories come from omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids. Other groups, including the European Commission (EU) and World Health Organization (WHO), have similar guidelines.

item.title: Cutting Calories may Boost Memory
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: In a recent study, older adults who reduced their calorie intake by about 30 percent performed better on memory tests.

item.title: Mercury Detected in Products Containing High-Fructose Corn Syrup
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Environmental Resources, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: Two new studies suggest that some foods and drinks made with high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS) may contain detectable levels of mercury, a toxic metal historically used as an antimicrobial.

item.title: Vitamin D and Cognitive Function
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study, published in the Journal of Geriatric Psychology and Neurology, suggests that low levels of vitamin D may be linked to an increased risk of cognitive impairment in older adults.

item.title: Soft Drinks and Kidney Disease
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: According to a recent cross-section study, drinking two servings of regular soda daily may increase the risk of kidney damage in women.

item.title: Immunotherapy Studied for Peanut Allergies
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: In a new study, children with peanut allergies experienced improved tolerance after taking low doses of peanut allergens that were gradually increased over time.

item.title: Calcium Associated with Reduced Risk of Digestive Cancers
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that calcium may help reduce the risk of digestive cancers in older adults.

item.title: B-Vitamins may Help Prevent AMD
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A recent study suggests that supplementation with B-vitamins may help prevent age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in older Americans.

item.title: Low Vitamin D Levels Linked to Colds
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Individuals with low levels of vitamin D may be more likely to catch colds or the flu, a new study suggests.

item.title: Many Cancers may be Preventable
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: According to a new report from the World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) and the American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR), about one-third of the 12 most common adult cancers may be preventable by making healthy lifestyle choices. The report did not include cancers that could be prevented by not smoking.

item.title: Working Long Hours Linked to Mental Decline
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: In a recent study, working long hours was associated with decreased cognitive function in middle-aged adults.

item.title: Oxygen Therapy Studied in Autistic Children
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) may offer some benefit to children with autism.

item.title: Maggot Therapy Studied as Treatment for Leg Ulcers
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that maggot therapy, a technique that uses live maggots to clean non-healing wounds, may be more painful and less effective for leg ulcers than standard treatment.

item.title: Drinking Hot Tea may be Linked to Esophageal Cancer
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: According to a new study published in the British Medical Journal, drinking hot black tea may increase the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma, the most common type of esophageal cancer.

item.title: Marijuana may Help Kill Brain Cancer Cells
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the main active component in marijuana, may help destroy brain cancer cells.

item.title: Drugs Found in Fish
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Environmental Resources, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: Researchers have found that fish living near waste water treatment plants in urban areas contained trace amounts of chemicals, including drugs used to treat allergies, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, and mood disorders.

item.title: Music Therapy May Improve Vision After Stroke
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Music therapy is widely known for its mood-enhancing and stress-reducing effects. Some researchers now speculate that positive emotional responses to music may help restore vision in stroke patients.

item.title: Potential Weight-Loss Effects of African Mango
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: An extract made from the African mango (Irvingia gabonensis) may help overweight people lose weight and lower their cholesterol levels, researchers report in the online journal Lipids in Health and Disease.

item.title: Red and Processed Meats May Be Unhealthy
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Health & Wellness, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: A recent study supports growing evidence that eating too much meat may be unhealthy. Researchers from the U.S. National Cancer Institute found that a diet rich in red and processed meats increased the risk of death, particularly from cancer and heart disease.

item.title: Coffee and Tea Linked to Lower Cancer Risk
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that drinking black tea and caffeinated coffee daily may be associated with a lower risk of endometrial cancer in women. Endometrial cancer affects the lining of the uterus and is most common among women who are between the ages of 60 and 70.

item.title: Heavy Drinking may Damage Teenage Brain
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that teenagers who binge drink may damage the “white matter” in their brains. This area of the brain contains nerve fibers and is involved in transmitting messages between brain cells. If it is damaged, it may affect thinking and memory.

item.title: Possible Weight-Loss Effects of White Tea
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: White tea may have weight-loss effects, according to a new lab study published in the journal Nutrition and Metabolism.

item.title: Warning Against Swine Flu Supplements
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: Several CAM organizations, including the American Herbal Products Association (AHPA), the Consumer Healthcare Products Association (CHPA), the Council for Responsible Nutrition (CRN), the Natural Products Association (NPA) and the United Natural Products Alliance (UNPA), are warning consumers about products that falsely claim to treat or prevent the H1N1 flu virus (swine flu).

item.title: Folic Acid may Improve Asthma, Allergies
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Folic acid, or vitamin B9, may help treat allergic reactions and allergy symptoms, according to researchers from the Johns Hopkins Children's Center.

item.title: Hydroxycut® Recalled
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that magnesium may help minimize nerve damage in newborns with low oxygen levels, a condition called perinatal asphyxia.

item.title: Magnesium for Infants with Low Oxygen Levels
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that magnesium may help minimize nerve damage in newborns with low oxygen levels, a condition called perinatal asphyxia.

item.title: Magnets for Migraines
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New animal research suggests that a noninvasive therapy called transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) may help treat chronic migraines.

item.title: Pomegranate for Prostate Cancer
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Pomegranate juice may be beneficial in men who have undergone standard treatment for localized prostate cancer, according to a long-term study presented at the 104th Annual Scientific Meeting of the American Urological Association.

item.title: State of the Air Report
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Environmental Resources
item.itunes:summary: The American Lung Association released its State of the Air: 2009 Report this month. The 10th annual report states that air pollution has significantly improved in some areas of the country, but major cities still have significant problems with pollutants.

item.title: Vitamin D May Not Affect Prostate Cancer Risk
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New evidence suggests that vitamin D may not decrease the risk of prostate cancer.

item.title: Wall Street Journal Interviews Natural Standard
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements
item.itunes:summary: Natural Standard Chief Editor Dr. Catherine Ulbricht helped the Wall Street Journal separate fact from fiction in a recent news article about the Chinese herb astragalus.

item.title: Aspirin Therapy Questioned
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new research analysis published in the Lancet questions traditional recommendations for daily, low-dose aspirin therapy.

item.title: Benefits of Natural Birthing Classes Unclear
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Learning relaxation and breathing techniques during pregnancy may not reduce the likelihood of needing an epidural or Caesarian section, researchers report in BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology.

item.title: Comfrey may Improve Back Pain
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: An ointment made from comfrey root extract may significantly reduce acute upper and lower back pain, according to a new study published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine.

item.title: Green Tea for Leukemia
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: Mayo Clinic researchers have found that a compound in green tea called epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) may have beneficial effects in patients with chonic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

item.title: Is Pollution Linked to Liver Disease?
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Environmental Resources, Evidence-Based Research, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: A new study suggests that environmental pollution may be associated with liver disease in the United States. The new data supports earlier evidence linking liver disease to highly exposed chemical workers.

item.title: Yellow Alder may Help Fight MRSA
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Evidence-Based Research, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Medical Conditions
item.itunes:summary: New laboratory evidence suggests that yellow alder (Turnera ulmifolia) extract may enhance the effects of antibiotics in the treatment of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). MRSA is a type of bacteria that does not respond to treatment with certain antibiotics, including ampicillin (Principen®) and other penicillins.

item.title: FDA Warning: Some Zicam Products may Impair Smell
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Allergy & Immunology, Foods, Herbs & Supplements, Product Advisories
item.itunes:summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has warned Matrixx Initiatives to stop selling three over-the-counter Zicam® products, marketed as cold remedies, after more than 130 people reported developing long-lasting or permanent loss of smell (called anosmia). item.title: Ethics of Chelation Study Questioned
item.itunes:author: Natural Standard
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence-Based Research, Health & Wellness, Medical Conditions

According to the report from the U.S. Office for Human Research Protections, researchers did not properly inform the participants of potential health risks. The probe also revealed that some of the researchers have been disciplined by state medical boards, and at least three are convicted felons.
